description.plain:
Melissa Arnette Elliott, sometimes known Missy “Misdemeanor” Elliott, or just simply Missy Elliot, was born on July 1, 1971. Many consider Missy Elliott as the best female rapper of the mid-1990s and early-2000’s. She began her musical career working in the all-female group Sista and later Swing Mob before beginning her solo career in 1997 with the release of her debut album Supa Dupa Fly. Supa Dupa Fly peaked at #3 on the Billboard 200 and sold over 1.2 million copies, giving Missy her first platinum certification.

She began the 2000s with three hit albums in a row, Miss E… So Addictive, Under Construction, and This Is Not a Test!. Missy has spent most of the last decade producing songs for other artists like Keyshia Cole, Jazmine Sullivan, and Monica.

songs.full_title: Work It by Missy Elliott
songs.title: Work It

description.plain:
“Work It' is the first single from Missy’s 2002 album Under Construction. The song was both a commercial and critical hit: It peaked at No. 2 on Billboard’s Hot 100 (making it Missy’s biggest hit) and was named the best single of 2002 in The Village Voice’s Pazz & Jop poll. The song memorably features backward lyrics and an elephant trumpting. It also helped popularize the term "badonkadonk.” The song is a raunchy ode where Missy raps about sexing up guys. In his review of Under Construction, allmusic’s John Bush said the song, “turns the tables on male rappers, taking charge of the sex game, matching their lewdest, rudest rhymes.”

This music video features the young hip hop dancer, Alyson Stoner, who in 2015 choreographed a tribute to Missy Elliott for “the opportunity to dance for [her] and now carve a path of [her] own.”

songs.full_title: WTF (Where They From) by Missy Elliott (Ft. Pharrell Williams)
songs.title: WTF (Where They From)

description.plain:
Rap legend Missy Elliott returned with her first single in 7 years, and it’s a platinum-certified hit. She enlists her old friend, longtime collaborator, and fellow Virginia native Pharrell Williams for the beat and second verse on this bouncy dance track.

The song peaked at #22 on the Billboard Hot 100 and #8 on the Billboard Hot R&B/Hip-Hop Charts. The incredible music video has amassed 50 million views (as of April 2017) on Youtube and takes Missy’s quirkiness up another notch.

songs.full_title: Get Ur Freak On by Missy Elliott
songs.title: Get Ur Freak On

description.plain:
“For those of you who hated,” Missy taunted at the beginning of “Lick Shots”, “you only made us more creative.” By that standard, the song that followed it on Miss E… So Addictive must’ve meant that her and Timbaland were the most-loathed artists of 2001. Eight years after it hit the top ten of Billboard’s Hot 100, “Get Ur Freak On” still sounds like an audaciously leftfield stroke of genius, a song that succeeded wildly in its goal to push futurism, global style, and flat-out hyper-manic absurdity to equally lofty heights. Timbaland’s flair for the accessibly exotic reached its peak here with his bhangra-meets-jungle beat and 50s B-movie sci-fi synths, replacing the stagger-step trap breaks of drum'n'bass with a burbling tabla and subsequently creating a uniquely slippery dance track that bumps hard without a single kick drum.

-Pitchfork, ranking it the 7th best track of 2000’s decade.

The music video was uploaded to Youtube on October 26, 2009.

songs.full_title: I'm Better by Missy Elliott (Ft. Cainon Lamb)
songs.title: I’m Better

description.plain:
In what seems to be becoming the norm, rather than the exception, Missy Elliot surprise-drops a modern masterpiece with a feature from Cainion Lamb, in his rap debut. Nearly 2 years after her Super Bowl performance with Katy Perry, Misdemeanor decided the time was now to make the official musical comeback.

I had everybody and their mother telling me [the Super Bowl] was the perfect time to drop something. Of course you should most definitely take advantage of the moment, but I believe that it has to be right. If you believe that what you can do can be classic or timeless. If you give them greatness, it’ll be worth the wait.

While filled with present-day references, cool lingo, and trap music similarities, “I’m Better” is still a Misdemeanor E track to the core – she brags and flaunts herself as being, well, better. The song was released exclusively on Apple Music on January 26, 2017, promoted with a Fact Magazine interview, followed up with the music video release on the next day, and on other platforms as well. The song peaked at #28 on the Billboard Hot R&B/Hip-Hop songs chart.

songs.full_title: The Rain (Supa Dupa Fly) by Missy Elliott
songs.title: The Rain (Supa Dupa Fly)

description.plain:
“The Rain” is as impressionistic as any lyric in rap; it sets a numinous mood. Furthermore,

this was Missy Elliott’s first single, and it also spawned her first music video. Timbaland produced and co-wrote the song and appeared in the video (the beginning of Elliott’s longtime collaboration with director Hype Williams until he was replaced by Dave Meyers). Elliott played up her size in the video by wearing an enormous inflated trash bag – a “screw you” to all the execs who told her she was too fat to make it in the music business.



The song samples “I Can’t Stand The Rain” by Ann Peebles.

songs.full_title: Lose Control by Missy Elliott (Ft. Ciara & Fatman Scoop)
songs.title: Lose Control

description.plain:
Another classic Missy Elliott banger, centered around the loss of control of your extremities on the dance floor. It samples Hot Streak’s “Body Work” and Cybotron’s “Clear.” Produced by Missy herself, this hit features Ciara, fresh off the hype of her incredible first album, Goodies, and Fatman Scoop as a hype man.

The video features a bunch of dancers engaging in futuristic moves in various settings, with Missy displaying cutting edge technology.

The song was a chart smash, making it to number 3 on the Billboard Hot 100, and top 10 in 4 other countries.

songs.full_title: One Minute Man by Missy Elliott (Ft. Ludacris & Trina)
songs.title: One Minute Man

description.plain:
“One Minute Man” was the second proper single from Missy Elliott’s 2001 Miss E… So Addictive album. Following the wild success of “Get Ur Freak On,” Missy eschews her usual rapping in favor of wearing a singers hat. She leaves the rapping for guests Trina and Ludacris to handle (and on the bonus remix, Jay Z as well).

This continues a similar formula from her two previous albums. On her debut Supa Dupa Fly, she followed the success of rap track “The Rain” with the sexually suggestive “Sock It 2 Me” featuring Missy as a singer and Da Brat as the rapper. Her sophomore release Da Real World continued that pattern with the ballsy rapping lead single “She’s A Bitch,” but immediately chasing it was the crooning-Missy single “All N My Grill” with rap by Outkast’s Big Boi.

“One Minute Man” continues the tradition of Missy’s candid yet comedic style well. Few other artists could sing a tongue-in-cheek R&B song about premature ejaculation with a straight face. Even with the taboo subject matter, the song still peaked at #15 on the Billboard Pop charts and #8 on R&B.

body.plain:
“One Minute Man” was the second proper single from Missy Elliott’s 2001 Miss E… So Addictive album. Following the wild success of “Get Ur Freak On,” Missy eschews her usual rapping in favor of wearing a singers hat. She leaves the rapping for guests Trina and Ludacris to handle (and on the bonus remix, Jay Z as well).

This continues a similar formula from her two previous albums. On her debut Supa Dupa Fly, she followed the success of rap track “The Rain” with the sexually suggestive “Sock It 2 Me” featuring Missy as a singer and Da Brat as the rapper. Her sophomore release Da Real World continued that pattern with the ballsy rapping lead single “She’s A Bitch,” but immediately chasing it was the crooning-Missy single “All N My Grill” with rap by Outkast’s Big Boi.

“One Minute Man” continues the tradition of Missy’s candid yet comedic style well. Few other artists could sing a tongue-in-cheek R&B song about premature ejaculation with a straight face. Even with the taboo subject matter, the song still peaked at #15 on the Billboard Pop charts and #8 on R&B.

songs.full_title: Bomb Intro/Pass That Dutch by Missy Elliott
songs.title: Bomb Intro/Pass That Dutch

description.plain:
Following quickly on the heels of her 2002 album Under Construction with its international smash hit “Work It,” Missy Elliott delivered “Pass That Dutch,” the lead single from her 2003 album This Is Not A Test!. The 808-laden, clap happy, and readily twerkable song was produced by Timbaland.

The dark-humored music video features the cartoonish special effects Missy has come to be known for. In one scene, she’s rapping as scarecrow in a corn field, while black-clad dancers execute choreography around her. Just as quickly, Missy morphs into a Fred “Rerun” Berry styled pop-lock dancer in a retro TV show. The following scene finds Missy riverdancing in a  cheerleader outfit. Oddly, the video begins with the interlude “Baby Girl” as a introduction and ends with a verse of “Wake Up” essentially introducing the viewer to the first 3 tracks on Missy’s album in the course of one music video.

songs.full_title: Sock It 2 Me by Missy Elliott (Ft. Da Brat)
songs.title: Sock It 2 Me

description.plain:
Sock It 2 Me is one of Missy biggest hits in 1997 through 1998, the video is also known for its interesting concept. It was written by Shawntae Harris, William Hart, Thom Bell and producer Timothy “Timbaland” Mosley for her debut album Supa Dupa Fly (1997) and released as the album’s second single in a slightly re-recorded form. The song’s beat directly samples the 1968 single “Ready or Not Here I Come (Can’t Hide from Love)” by the Delfonics.

The music video, directed by Hype Williams, was inspired by the Mega Man video game series and features Elliott and her dancers doing Michael Jackson’s “Smooth Criminal” dance.

description.plain: The third track on Missy’s album Da Real World, “Busa Rhyme” is definitely the most explicit and violent tracks on the album. This is due to the presence of one ‘Slim Shady,’ the alter ego of Eminem. On this track, Tim allows both Em and Missy to go off, with Em talking about his dick, punching a pregnant woman, and jumping out of the 93rd floor of a building. While Missy talks about how somebody ‘pissed her off’ and her reaction. This hook of this song samples “Play That Funky Music” by Wild Cherry.

description.plain: This is the third version of Missy’s hit single. It was included as a bonus track on her third studio album Miss E… So Addictive. The track incorporates elements of oriental music, and samples the Timbaland Remix of Lenny Kravitz’s 1999 hit single ‘American Woman’ and David Pomeranz’s 1976  song ‘Greyhound Mary’.

songs.full_title: She's a Bitch by Missy Elliott
songs.title: She’s a Bitch

description.plain: “She’s a Bitch” is the lead single for Da Real World.  The song uses the word “bitch” as both negative and empowering. Despite promotion for the song, it only peaked at #90 on the Billboard Hot 100 and #30 on Billboard’s Hot R&B/Hip-Hop Songs. The music video for the song was included on the Enhanced CD version of the album but it wasn’t released to YouTube until October of 2009.

description.plain: Missy sings about someone who wants to be with her, but doesn’t do the things to keep her. This typical player uses then leaves her without offering much. This is not a reciprocal relationship, so she really doesn’t have time to deal with them unless they can step up and bring something to the table (specifically, some ‘ends). This remix features the french rapper MC Solaar (rapping in french) and was primarily released in Europe.

songs.full_title: Pep Rally by Missy Elliott
songs.title: Pep Rally

description.plain:
To coincide with Missy’s Amazon Echo Superbowl 50 commercial cameo, she released “Pep Rally” via Twitter on the 8th of February.

https://twitter.com/MissyElliott/status/696411665567498240?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw

It’s her second release since November, when “WTF (Where They From)” dropped out of nowhere.

description.plain: The 2nd single from Missy’s 1999 album, Da Real World, features vocal ad-libs from one time protégé Nicole Wray and a verse from Outkast’s Big Boi. This song had more success than the first single, “She’s A Bitch” which only reached #90 on the Billboard Hot 100 where as this one peaked at #64 on the Billboard Hot 100.

description.plain: “Ching-A-Ling” is the lead single from the soundtrack Step Up 2 the Streets. It was also suppose to appear on Missy’s unreleased seventh album Block Party. It peaked at #60 on the Billboard Hot 100 and is #69 on Rolling Stone’s 100 Best Songs of 2008. The music video was released to Youtube on October 26, 2009.

songs.full_title: Hit 'Em Wit' Da Hee by Missy Elliott (Ft. Lil' Kim)
songs.title: Hit ‘Em Wit’ Da Hee
songs.title_with_featured: Hit 'Em Wit' Da Hee (Ft. Lil' Kim)

description.plain: Friends, Missy and (Lil') Kim, Vibe together on this track. Kim kicks off the track with a fiery guest verse, which is actually quite interesting. Missy decided to have two established artists contributing to her album before she even graces the stage with first her finest vocals and then shows off her funky flow on the second verse. I imagine that having 2 major artists talking her up before she even says a word, is to really show that she deserves the hype (and the 2 Hype Williams directed music videos on her debut album).

songs.full_title: Back in the Day by Missy Elliott (Ft. JAY-Z)
songs.title: Back in the Day

description.plain: The 5th track on Missy’s Under Construction, “Back in the Day” focuses on the ‘good old days’ of hip-hop and gives an insight as to what those days were like for those that don’t know. The song features JAY-Z which makes this their second collaboration after the “One Minute Man (Remix)” from her previous album, Miss E… So Addictive.

songs.full_title: Can You Hear Me by Missy Elliott (Ft. TLC)
songs.title: Can You Hear Me

description.plain: This is a dedication song on Missy Elliot’s “Under Construction” album to Aaliyah Dana Haughton who died in a plane crash on August 25,2001 in the Bahamas at the age of 21. It is also dedicated to Lisa “Lefteye” Lopes (1/3 of super girl-group TLC) who died on April 25, 2002 (eight months after Aaliyah’s death) in a car crash at Honduras. She was 30 years old.

songs.full_title: Get Ur Freak On (Nelly Furtado Remix) by Missy Elliott (Ft. Nelly Furtado)
songs.title: Get Ur Freak On (Nelly Furtado Remix)
songs.title_with_featured: Get Ur Freak On (Nelly Furtado Remix) (Ft. Nelly Furtado)

description.plain:
“https://genius.com/Missy-elliott-get-your-freak-on-lyrics” is a song by American recording artist https://genius.com/artists/Missy-elliott Missy “Misdemeanor” Elliott. It was written and produced by Elliott and https://genius.com/artists/Timbaland for her third studio album Miss E  … So Addictive https://genius.com/albums/Missy-elliott/Miss-e-so-addictive (2001).

The song is based on heavy bhangra elements, a popular music and dance form from the Punjab state of India, the song features a six-note base that is a Punjabi melody played on a tumbi (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tumbi), a stringed Indian instrument.

Released as the album’s first single in 2001, the track reached number seven on the US Billboard Hot 100 chart.

“Get Your Freak On” Official Music Video: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=FPoKiGQzbSQ

Internationally, “Get Ur Freak On” became a top ten success in the Netherlands and the United Kingdom, where it became her first solo top ten hit, peaking at number four.

In December, the song was listed 14th on Rolling Stone‍‍ '​‍s Best Songs of the Decade ranking, and later at number 466 on their https://genius.com/Rolling-stone-the-500-greatest-songs-of-all-time-lyrics updated list of 2010.

In 2002, “Get Ur Freak On” was named the best single released in the year 2001 by The Village Voice‍ '​s Pazz & Jop annual year-end critics' poll. The song also lists at number seven on Pitchfork Media’s Top 500 Songs of the 2000s and number 16 on VH1’s Greatest Songs of Hip-Hop. In 2011, NME placed it at number 17 on its list 150 Best Tracks of the Past 15 Years.In April 2014, the song was remixed with https://genius.com/artists/The-black-keys song https://genius.com/The-black-keys-keep-me-lyrics on their third studio album, https://genius.com/albums/The-black-keys/Rubber-factory Rubber Factory, for the original soundtrack to Neighbors.

The Black Keys | “Keep Me”:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Eg1sV4eDAVY

On the Billboard magazine issue dated February 21, 2015, “Get Ur Freak On” re-entered at #40, more than a decade after its original chart run. This re-entry was spawned by Missy Elliott’s performance with https://genius.com/artists/Katy-perry at the Super Bowl XLIX halftime show.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=S6k4i4ZGJeE&list=RDkK5PC7i11DM&index=2
